\section{Input Current / Input Current Density}
\label{_static/Tutorial:input-current-input-current-density}
The method from HodgkinHuxley.py takes the input in as a current density in the form of uA/cm\textasciicircum{}2.  NeuroML/LEMS uses an input current in the form of nA, which requires a conversion in the input values.

This method from HodgkinHuxley.py:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\},numbers=left,firstnumber=1,stepnumber=1]
    \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{I\PYGZus{}inj}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{l+s+sd}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{        External Current}

\PYG{l+s+sd}{        \textbar{}  :param t: time}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{        \textbar{}  :return: step up to 10 uA/cm\PYGZca{}2 at t\PYGZgt{}100}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{        \textbar{}           step down to 0 uA/cm\PYGZca{}2 at t\PYGZgt{}200}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{        \textbar{}           step up to 35 uA/cm\PYGZca{}2 at t\PYGZgt{}300}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{        \textbar{}           step down to 0 uA/cm\PYGZca{}2 at t\PYGZgt{}400}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{        \PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}}
        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{100}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{200}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+m+mi}{35}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{300}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{l+m+mi}{35}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{400}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

By using a given surface area of 1000.0 um\textasciicircum{}2 in the cell, it makes the conversion from uA/cm\textasciicircum{}2 to nA easier.
\begin{quote}

\textbf{Insert explanation of how to go from 1000.0 um\textasciicircum{}2 to 17.841242}
\end{quote}

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
            \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}segment} \PYG{n+na}{id=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}0\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{n+na}{name=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}soma\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZgt{}}
                \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}proximal} \PYG{n+na}{x=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}0\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{n+na}{y=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}0\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{n+na}{z=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}0\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{n+na}{diameter=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}17.841242\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{n+nt}{/\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{c}{\PYGZlt{}!\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{c}{Gives a convenient surface area of 1000.0 um\PYGZca{}2}\PYG{c}{\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}\PYGZgt{}}
                \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}distal} \PYG{n+na}{x=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}0\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{n+na}{y=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}0\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{n+na}{z=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}0\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{n+na}{diameter=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}17.841242\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{n+nt}{/\PYGZgt{}}
            \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}/segment\PYGZgt{}}
\end{Verbatim}

Given a surface area of 1000.0 um\textasciicircum{}2 in the cell the following equation is used to convert from X uA/cm\textasciicircum{}2 to Y nA:
\begin{gather}
\begin{split}(X  uA/cm^2) * (1000.0  um^2) * (1000  nA/uA) / (1 * 10^8  um^2/cm^2) = Y nA\end{split}\notag
\end{gather}
Line 11 can then be translated into the delay, duration and amplitude of the two pulseGenerator objects in NML2\_SingleCompHHCell.nml:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

    \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZlt{}pulseGenerator} \PYG{n+na}{id=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}pulseGen2\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{n+na}{delay=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}300ms\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{n+na}{duration=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}100ms\PYGZdq{}} \PYG{n+na}{amplitude=}\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}0.35nA\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{n+nt}{/\PYGZgt{}}

\item[] step up to 35 uA/cm\textasciicircum{}2 at t\textgreater{}300
\item[] step down to 0 uA/cm\textasciicircum{}2 at t\textgreater{}400
\end{DUlineblock}
